security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based documentation skill with no executable code. Contains only guidelines and example commands for legitimate GitHub PR review workflows. All operations require explicit user confirmation.

content.user_title: Resolve GitHub PR review comments systematically
content.value_statement: Managing PR review comments manually is time-consuming and error-prone. This skill prioritizes comments by severity, applies fixes with user confirmation, and automatically replies to resolved threads using proper commit formats.
actual_capabilities: Fetches PR comments using GitHub CLI (gh api)
Classifies comments by severity: CRITICAL, HIGH, MEDIUM, LOW
Applies code fixes with user confirmation before changes
Creates properly formatted commits referencing comment IDs
Posts thread replies using standard response templates
Verifies fixes and runs tests before pushing
limitations: Requires GitHub CLI (gh) to be installed and authenticated
Does not modify code without explicit user approval
Cannot access private repositories without proper GitHub authentication
Does not resolve merge conflicts automatically

use_cases.title: Process team code reviews
use_cases.description: Systematically address colleague feedback on pull requests with proper prioritization and documentation

use_cases.title: Manage contributor PRs
use_cases.description: Efficiently handle multiple review comments from community contributors with consistent workflow

use_cases.title: Enforce review standards
use_cases.description: Apply consistent severity classification and commit formatting across all reviewed pull requests

prompt_templates.title: Basic PR comment resolution
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants to address PR feedback
prompt_templates.prompt: Resolve the PR review comments for the current pull request. Start by fetching all comments, classify by severity, and show me what needs to be fixed.

prompt_templates.title: Critical security fixes
prompt_templates.prompt: There are security-related review comments on this PR. Fetch them with HIGH or CRITICAL severity and help me fix each one immediately.

prompt_templates.title: Batch style fixes
prompt_templates.prompt: Process all MEDIUM and LOW severity comments on this PR. Group the cosmetic fixes into a single style commit.

prompt_templates.title: Complete review workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Do a complete review comment workflow: fetch all comments, prioritize by severity, fix each one with my approval, commit properly, reply to threads, run tests, and prepare for merge.

best_practices: Always read project conventions (CLAUDE.md) before starting to understand commit style and coding standards
Confirm with the user before applying each fix, especially for CRITICAL and HIGH severity comments
Run tests after applying fixes and before pushing to ensure all changes work correctly
anti_patterns: Skipping user confirmation before making code changes
Ignoring CRITICAL or HIGH severity comments without explicit approval
Not replying to resolved comment threads, leaving conversations open
Batching all fixes together instead of separating functional and cosmetic changes

faq.question: Which tools does this skill work with?
faq.answer: GitHub CLI (gh) and git. Requires gh to be installed and authenticated with GitHub access.

faq.question: How many comments can it process at once?
faq.answer: The skill can process unlimited comments but prioritizes CRITICAL and HIGH severity issues first.

faq.question: Can it integrate with CI/CD systems?
faq.answer: The skill runs tests locally but does not directly integrate with CI/CD systems like GitHub Actions.

faq.question: Is my code or data safe?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill only reads PR comments and requires explicit user confirmation before any code modifications.

faq.question: What if tests fail after fixes?
faq.answer: The skill instructs you to not push until tests pass. It will report test failures so you can address them.

faq.question: How is this different from other GitHub skills?
faq.answer: This skill specifically handles PR review comments with severity classification and thread replies. Use git-commit for commits and pr-merge for merging.
